results.title: Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion [exhibition] : archival material
results.brief_description:
“Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion” was an ACMI Screen Gallery Exhibition, held 26 October 2002 - 27 January 2003.
See Exhibition activity record “Deep Space” (ID 3) for more information
The international and Australian contemporary artists in this exibition present environments, or chambers, for the visitor to participate in an all encompassing aesthetic experience. The audience is invited to move within the art works, to explore their physical construction, their digital presence, their filmic pulse and their saturated expanses of colour and light. The experiences vary: some are quiet, some intangible, others humourous or uncanny. Each involves an ephemeral medium, whether it be light, video or digital imagery and each encloses the viewer in a confined space only to offer them access to another expanded sense of space altogether. This exhibition offers visitors a memorable and transformative experience of being immersed in ‘deep space’, the kineasthetic, visual, aural and informational totality of the art works.

results.title: Hold: Vessel #1 and Vessel #2
results.material_description: video, projection, glass, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
Hold: Vessel 1 is a magical interactive experience in which visitors to the gallery try to catch a mesmerizing series of projected visions in a delicate glass bowl - echoing the wondrous views of the world made possible with the first microscopes, underwater cameras and astronomical cinematography.
Lynette Wallworth began her career in photography, and has also worked in short film, installation and performance. She creates installation spaces that require activation by the participant/viewer. To collect the images used in Hold: Vessel 1 she collaborated with scientific image libraries and specialist cinematographers, as part of her ongoing investigation into imaging technologies that enable us to see the world in ways otherwise inaccessible to the naked human eye. Hold: Vessel 1 consists of video projections with directional sound scape beamed from above into a darkened space. The visitor is invited to take hold of a glass bowl and catch the images within it, finding the point at which the vision is most clear and resolved. A personal portal opens to us as we cradle the bowl in our hands. Imagery in ‘Hold’ is derived mainly from Australian scientists and specialist cinematographers including: David Hannan, who has adapted medical imaging technology to film extreme macro images of the Great Barrier Reef, Anya Salih, who investigates coral fluorescence and Greg Rouse, Marine Biologist. The work is designed as a vessel to hold a changing pool of imagery. Hold: Vessel 1 will change in time as time changes the environments it reflects.

results.title: Run for our rights
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @aiww's instagram feed
results.brief_description: Chinese artist Ai Wei Wei is campaigning against threats to journalistic free speech by encouraging others to post videos of themselves “running for our rights”. Australian journalist Julian Assange gave Ai Wei Wei a treadmill he used while living at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assange faces potential extradition and prison in America for publishing US government documents on Wikileaks.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Chinese artist Ai Wei Wei is campaigning against threats to journalistic free speech by encouraging others to post videos of themselves “running for our rights”. Australian journalist Julian Assange gave Ai Wei Wei a treadmill he used while living at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assange faces potential extradition and prison in America for publishing US government documents on Wikileaks.
description_for_label: Chinese artist Ai Wei Wei is campaigning against threats to journalistic free speech by encouraging others to post videos of themselves “running for our rights”. Australian journalist Julian Assange gave Ai Wei Wei a treadmill he used while living at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assange faces potential extradition and prison in America for publishing US government documents on Wikileaks.

results.title: Scottsman drops his turkey
results.brief_description: We’re on the slippery slope towards Christmas, that hectic time of year when we rush around desperately trying to get everything done. Come Christmas dinner we can relax a bit, the work is done and we get to enjoy the fruits of our labours, unless you’re this guy…
results.description:

display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: 9 News Covid-19 press conference
results.brief_description: At a recent NSW Covid-19 press conference, authorities revealed they’d fined two nudists for sunbaking outside in defiance of stay-at-home-orders. While that’s revealed to be contentious (they were inside the border), the fact that the duo needed to be rescued after being startled by a deer and getting lost in a forest brought some light-heartedness to the dour proceedings. The Auslan interpretation of the story also tickled Twitter users.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

At a recent NSW Covid-19 press conference, authorities revealed they’d fined two nudists for sunbaking outside in defiance of stay-at-home orders. While that’s revealed to be contentious (they were inside the designated area), the fact that the duo needed to be rescued after being startled by a deer and getting lost in a forest brought some much-needed light-heartedness to the otherwise dour proceedings.

As ABC producer Justin Stevens’ simple caption of ‘2021’ highlights, we’re living through an unusual and absurd age when these types of things seem the norm. Not to mention the lively Auslan interpretation of ‘sunbathing naked’ and ‘deer’, which was quickly turned into a meme and propelled the virality of the moment across social media.

Aside from being a humorous moment, it also highlighted the importance and highly skilled work of the unnamed interpreter, with one Twitter user commenting, “The woman who managed to do the Auslan today deserves credit.”

As Pedestrian TV reported: “Despite all the anxiety-riddled brouhaha that the global pandemic has beset upon us all, one of the great (and few) shining lights has been the, well, light shining upon the string of Auslan interpreters who have gamely stood next to Premiers and Chief Health Officers and interpreted complex, often rapid-fire information on the fly.”

These live-streamed press conferences also offer the public the opportunity to see the production of media and politics, allowing users to interact with breaking news and opine in real-time on social media, rather than just passively receive announcements from the government.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

At a recent NSW Covid-19 press conference, authorities revealed they’d fined two nudists for sunbaking outside in defiance of stay-at-home orders. While that’s now contentious (they were inside the border), the fact that the duo needed to be rescued after being startled by a deer and getting lost in a forest brought some light-heartedness to the dour proceedings. Keep an eye on the Auslan interpretation, which also tickled Twitter users.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Memory Garden
results.brief_description:
Filming ourselves and sharing the footage isn’t a modern phenomenon inspired by smart phones. It goes back to the first film in 1888 with Louis Le Prince’s ‘Roundhay Garden Scene’, a silent short of his family at home that demonstrates how we’ve always seen ourselves, friends and family as interesting subjects.

As advancements in technology led to more portable and affordable cameras, amateur filmmakers continued documenting their lives; capturing the everyday and extraordinary moments that moved and made us long before we were sharing selfies. These recorded memories have become an archive of our private lives and public history that preserves forgotten times, places and experiences.

constellations_primary.name: Making home movies
constellations_primary.description: Home movies have inspired the form and plots of narrative cinema.
